headline: Coquito
description: Try this coquito recipe for a coconut-flavored, eggnog-like holiday beverage from Puerto Rico. Cold, creamy coconut flavor delivers tropical holiday vibes!

video.description: This tropical version of eggnog adds a festive touch at the holidays.
video.name: Coquito

name: Coquito

recipeInstructions.text: Combine evaporated milk and egg yolks in the top of a double boiler over simmering water. Cook over the simmering water, stirring constantly, until mixture is thick enough to coat the back of a spoon, and reaches a temperature of 160 degrees F (71 degrees C).
Transfer mixture to a blender. Add cream of coconut, sweetened condensed milk, rum, water, vanilla, cinnamon, and cloves; blend until combined, about 30 seconds.
Pour into glass bottles and chill 8 hours to overnight before serving.

review.reviewBody: I am a Puerto Ricn Chef who specializes in Comida Criolla. Coquito does not have egg in the traditional recioe is actually made with real coconuts the real nuts are who put egg into it. Taste a whole alot better without also mix it by hand not in a blender.
Best Recipe I've used to make it in a long time. Remind me of my abuelo's recip. We'll definitely keep this one in my recipe book to do over and over again.

Great recipe. I use coconut milk in the can instead of coconut cream, this way you can skip the water and add more booze. If you temper your egg yolks properly it's WAY more tasty. Edge your serving glass with shaved coconut flakes! Use bacon fat on the rim if your doing small portions

I loved it. The rum is there to dilute the sweetness of the drink so if you make it virgin remember to add something that won't add too much more sugar to the drink like coconut water or it will be too sweet. I use coconut flavored rum (Don Q) and coconut water so as to not diminish the coconut flavor. I wouldn't recommend any spiced rums unless you are into that. It would take away from the subtle taste of the coconut. If you are a traditionalist then go through the extra work of squeezing the milk from ground coconut so it tastes like your grandmother's, otherwise save yourself time and the extra labor by getting good quality coconut milk. I am parcial to the Goya brand. Buen provecho.

I use this coquito recipe every year because I love it so much. Since I don't like eggs in my coquito, I omit the eggs and water and add an extra can of evaporated milk instead. Since eggs don't have to be cooked I just throw everything directly in the blender, except for the 2nd can of evaporated milk (because it doesn't fit), pour it into a pitcher, and stir in the 2nd can. Usually gone within hours in my family.
This is my favorite Coquito recipe. It comes out great every year! I make 3-4 bottles each Christmas and it goes fast!
Awesome, easy and delicious!
OMG....my new holiday favorite hands down.! Thank You. I just doubled recipe (and extra rum!) It was DELICIOUS!! I think next time I will double and add a extra can of cream of coconut.
I’ve made this two years in a row and it’s so delicious. Only thing I did different was add a cup of rum. It’s not too strong not too sweet it’s just perfect. It’s so easy to make also my go to!

Yummy and enjoyed by all. I use an amber rum instead. I just think it makes the taste a bit smoother.
The most time consuming part is heating the eggs and evaporated milk.

Yum! While I love coquito, I find it to be a bit too sweet for my taste and for that matter, I didn’t use the full can of cream of coconut nor condensed milk - used about 3/4 of condensed and about half can of cream of coconut. Did not use cloves, and initially did not add the water since it’s not in any other coquito recipes, but after chilling, it became quite thick and I did end up adding the water, which did not change the taste nor the texture, just thinned it a bit. Have made it a couple of times since my first attempt. Definitely recommend.

my husband and kids (obviously no alcohol for the kids) absolutely this!!! this is my one and only go to coquito recipe make it every year for the holidays and its a HUGE HIT its usually gone the same day its ready

Worst Coquito recipe. In the sense that this is a recipe for eggnog. I’ve had Coquito, never made it myself. But this taste nothing like it. And taste everything like a eggnog. If you’re looking for an eggnog recipe this is great. Otherwise go somewhere else. Disappointed
A PS to my previous review: I decided to see how it tasted in coffee. Heavenly.
Followed the recipe exactly and it’s amazing!
This is so delicious
Very rich and tasty. My husband loves it. Yes will make it again. Tastes better after it sits in fridge a few days so flavors meld. I didn’t add water but added the extra 1/2 cup of rum.

Great recipe but this is called Ponche. Over the years people have associated egg Ponche with Coquito. Traditional Coquito does not have eggs and uses real coconut. Love both but prefer Ponche just a little because it is thicker. 

Try it also with a real cinnamon stick and leave it whole in the bottle. 

A variation also adds a bit of maraschino cherries and juice to give it a different taste.

Oh.. and these drinks are served in much smaller glasses than in the video. I would say a serving should be 2-3 ounces.

This is a very good and easy recipe. I have made it several times and my friends and family love it. This season I tried a couple of changes that I think really made it even easier and quicker to make without changing the quality at all. I didn’t use the eggs (that cut down significantly on the time), and I used 1 cup of Rum and 1 can of Coconut Milk (instead of water). The yield is still 2 full 750 ml bottles and it was just as thick and creamy as it was when I used the eggs.
This is a keeper I do enjoy dark spiced rum instead but this is a delicious treat my friends always request during the holidays

Just made this tonight! Soooooo good! I couldn't wait to chill it overnight so I put a glass in the freezer and I am drinking it now. I did not change any of the ingredients but I didn't blend it because I don't have a blender. I was worried at first because the condensed milk and eggs didn't get thick for me. I then put that in a mixing bowl and added all of the other ingredients. I just stirred it with a whisk. Now that it has been chilled, it thickened up. I LOVE coquito and I am so glad I can now make it! I will be making it again next week for my family. Thank you so much!
Instead of eggs, I substituted it with Coco Lopez Coconut Milk. I also added Malibu Rum along with Bacardi Rum. It's so yummy!

I have been making coquito for years. As a NY Puerto Rican, I have been enjoying this delicious beverage since I can remember. This recipe is the real deal. There is no need to look any further!! Trust me, I have tried them all and this is the end of the road for me because there is no better recipe, and it's easy to make too! Just for preferences sake, I add more rum but that's just personal taste! A++++++ thanks so much for sharing the recipe :)

I’ve never had the real thing so I can’t judge the authenticity. It was truly delicious though. I followed the directions pretty much exactly except that I replaced coconut milk for the water. I used Bacardi Superior and added ice to my container before serving. It didn’t taste watered down at all and the alcohol content was pretty high. Everything raved about it and I thought it was pretty easy to make. I mixed the eggs and evaporated milk on medium almost constantly. I used a handheld thermometer to check the temp.
All the ingredients perfect except for the alcohol content..

Delicious! 
I did not have a double boiler, so I used a small pot with water and a big pot on top to do so and it wouldn't thicken. So I placed the pot with the eggs and milk onto the burner and cooked it on low-medium (3 on induction), and it thickened right up! 
I did not put the rum into it (so it is really thick), because I will add the rum individually. This recipe made 1 quart.
This was so easy and it tastes delicious.
Great recipe. Try substituting the rum for Hennessy it’s amazing!
Love it!!!! This recipe was a big hit with my family today!!!! Everyone loved it.
This is awesome! I've never had authentic coquito but I will continue to make this recipe. I cooked over medium heat in a pan. Doubled the rum. Very good!
Left out the cloves and used rum 151. Came out absolutely awesome!!! Introduced it to several people and every was blown away.
This is the best recipe for coquito! It was delicious. I put coconut milk instead of water like Brandy said on the review, it came out perfect.

The best Coquito I’ve tasted yet. I tweeked a little because the egg yokes thickened it quite a bit, but that was fine I just added more rum?? and let it completely cool in the refrigerator and run it through the blender one more time for about 30 seconds and then bottled it.
Way too sweet and not enough rum.
Great recipe! Love that it’s quick. My usual recipe has eggs, but you don’t cook it. It has to sit for 10 days. So I like that this was quick and easy.
Delicious, very creamy (maybe a little too thick but I think I cooked the egg mixture bit too much), I doubled the rum and it was perfect :)

Loved it at first, but it’s beyond sweet. The cream of coconut plus the condensed milk is sugar overkill! However I will remake it substituting coconut milk for the cream of coconut and nix the water while adding more rum! Flavors were great though!
The recipe states the yield of 10 servings, how many ounces per serving?
I doubled the rum because it was too sweet and didnt have enough kick for my taste. Otherwise its delicious, ive never had coquito before and decided to give it a try for a party tonight.
Used gingerbread spice mix as I didn't have separate cloves and cinnamon. Also omitted the water and doubled the rum. Turned out pretty good!

I made it but I'm not rating it yet, it got lumpy and tasted gritty.

Anyone who has made this maybe tell me what I did wrong before i try it again?
Took out the egg
Took this to a house party. The guests that had it all complimented its flavor.

Great Coquito Recipe, I make it every year and always get asked for the recipe. I do alter it to make it less sweet and it comes out delicious! Instead of the 1 (14 ounce) can sweetened condensed milk, I use half a can. I use a cup of white rum and 1 cup of water instead of the 1/2 suggested. Instead of ground cloves and cinnamon, I use the sticks and boil the cup of water. I like to infuse the flavor of cinnamon and cloves in the water and then garnish ground cinnamon when ready to serve. Hope this helps!

Let me preface that I love sweet and sugar. But this is VERY sweet. It is too sweet. I made this exactly as recipe listed. I had the pleasure of tasting coquito made by my friends Puerto Rican grandmother and I have yet to find a recipe that duplicates how she made it which was phenomenal. Sorry but I won’t be making this again.
This was awesome! I used more rum, no water, and brought it to Christmas in mini mason jars for everyone. Definitely going to make this again.
Delicious everyone loved it.
Love this simple recipe. Added more than 1/2 cup water to cut the sweetness of an entire can of sweetened condensed milk. Otherwise it is too rich for our taste because we like more than one shot!

I love this recipe. I think this recipe used to be called Coquito I. I like the eggs in this recipe bc I'm from Honduras and we make something similar with lots of egg yolks. I doubled the rum and used Bacardi dark. Came out yummy.
Add 1 cup of rum, otherwise so good!
Last year I did this exact recipe, it was good.
It’s delicious! I have some I purchased and it’s just as good. I followed the recipe and it’s great. (I will allow those who’d like to add more rum if they’d like).
Yummy! This recipe is delicious :) it was fairly easy to make and it turned out great. Will make it again:)

Best coquito I’ve ever had hands down. I make it every year and my family goes nuts for it. I follow the creator’s recipe and just mix the egg yolks and evaporated milk on the stovetop. It is creamy and sweet and coconut-y. My husband says it’s so addictive he may need coquito rehab after the holidays are over.

I made a double batch of this for a holiday party at work and everyone LOVED it. Even those that said they don’t like eggnog. I followed other reviewers suggestions and simmering on the stovetop and I replaced the water with coconut milk. After a taste test the following day I felt like it was too sweet and did not have enough Bacardi. I topped off the bottles with a lot more rum which helped cut the sweetness just right. For the double batch I used about half of a 750 mL bottle of Bacardi and it definitely tasted boozy without being too strong. I’m definitely making this again since it was incredibly easy and tasty!
Omg !! So good, I love it!!! Thanks for sharing.
My husband made this recipe for thanksgiving, with no revisions, and it was a hit!!!! We're making it again for another gathering since everyone loved it so much!
I have family in puertorico and this basically is the recipe they use. Definitely make the day before. If not two days before. Watch yourself though because this will get you TURNED UP. LOL!
Will be making some more before thanksgiving.

I dont have a double boiler so I just constantly stirred the evaporated milk and egg yolks on a medium heat until it was thick as other reviewers said. I also doubled the amount of rum and left out the water (I like my drinks on the stronger side). After I bottled it to put in the fridge, I put some cinnamon sticks in the bottles.
This by far is the best coquito I've ever tasted! I've bought a bunch from other people over the years, and now that I've found this recipe I'll never buy it from someone again since it's so simple to make! Great recipe!

I love this recipe. I'm Puertorrican and it never fails to please. I have people asking me for coquito all year long. 
Some alterations I've made are eliminating the 1/2 cup of water and simply using a cup of Don Q. 
I add whole cloves, vanilla extract and cinnamon sticks while the evaporated milk is boiling and strain them out when adding the mixture to the rest in the mixer, and it really brings out those flavors without creating the sediment the ground stuff makes.

Really good, a little on the sweet side, which is what it is suppose to be, but for my liking a little too sweet. I also added some nutmeg. Overall delish! 
Thx
Very creamy and delicious
Next time I would omit the vanilla and double or triple the rum. This is a good starter recipe though.
Yummy! I had only tried it once before but it was just as I remembered it.
OUTstanding recipe!! Made it, shared it, LOVED it! Real easy!

This came out quite good! I only made one small change: I used Leche de coconut instead of crema de coconut. 

Everyone loved the taste and I will have to make it again and again and again!

We received Coquito as a gift from a neighbor, but no longer live in the neighborhood. Since the whole family loved it and it was missing from our holiday routine, I decided to try this. WeI like it. I added extra rum instead of water. A dash of nutmeg, and because our gift version had included it, coconut flakes. Delish!!!

Wow! This is almost too good. Like eggnog, only better - not as sweet and not as gloopy and heavy. I've never been a fan of cloves, so I only added a sprinkle of them and added some freshly grated ginger and nutmeg. I wasn't quite sure what the recipe meant by coconut cream (Pepe Lopez?), so I used two 5.5 ounce cans of unsweetened coconut cream - the super thick, stiff stuff. I also added about a 1/4 of orange juice to brighten the taste. Excellent!
I added a cup of rum (2 cups altogether) and left out the water. Delicious!
Made the recipe exactly as is and it's delicious!
I've used this recipe for the last 2 years and it is amazing.
Make this exactly as the recipe...was one of the most amazing things I've ever tasted! This will definitely become a new favourite for Christmas!!! :)
The best coquito!!! Every holiday season, my co-workers and family can't wait for me to make it!!

Remember that Rum/alcohol in any drink is always to taste. My sister is a wimp so I reduced the alcohol to suit any taste. U can always add more!!! I make mine with more rum but not everyone like alcohol like some of us do and therefore the water. Those who think this is sweet should not be searching for eggnog!!! I am puertorican so don't let my name fool u. Anything other than coconut flavor is NOT coquito :p. This is my recipe and it was changed by all recipes to use a double boiler. You don't need to use a double boiler in my opinion as long as the eggs are fresh. If allergic to eggs, you could ommit them altogether and it won't change the flavor much; if at all. It will be just less thick and of course and eggless eggnog :). Instead of plain water I sometimes use coconut milk if I have it on hand. Coconut water will make it a bit salty and the use of coconut milk instead of coconut water is recommended or just use plain water. You still need the coconut cream for the coquito regardless so don't confuse the two.
This is exactly how it should taste! I loved it!

This is the way my family in Puerto Rico makes it. There are simpler ways but they just don't end up this creamy and delicious.
**NOTE** Most use a white rum like Bacardi but Captain Morgans is my new preferred rum in coquito. It adds even more flavor.
Perfect!!!Couldn't come out better than this :-)

I've made this many times before even have had request to make it for birthdays during the year. This year people have asked for me to make this for them. I don't want to make it at the last minute. How long does it last in fridge after making?

Living in the islands and so close to the spanish culture, I must say that my family and friends raved over this! It was awesome!!!! I used our local coconut cruzian rum for the recipe. It's absolutely the best rum for this recipe! Will make this every Christmas season as I no longer need to buy a bottle and hope the person's recipe is as good as this!

Every Christmas Eve, I make this drink for my coworkers. It is a yearly tradition at work now. I also bring empanadas as well and all my coworkers look forward to them every year. I've found that one can of condensed milk is too sweet, so I cut it down to about 3/4 cup. My daughter loves the non alcoholic kind. Sweet, creamy and delicious. It is not Christmas without it!

This is the second time I made this. I didn't change a thing except doubling up and placing a cinnamon stick in the bottle. I made enough to fill a 1.75l bottle plus 16 ounces. Tastes great with the correct amount of rum. P.s. I bought cheap white rum.

Delicious! I'm half puertorican and followed this recipe completely and found that it tastes just like what I am used to and have drinken while 2 decades in PR. Now that I'm back in the U.S. just had to have it to make it for my hubby who loved iit! Just added a bit more rum but dark (Bacardi Gold) and 1 can coconut water came out perfect!! Thanks!
I hate eggnog ok. HATE IT. That said I love this. Yummy coconutty goodness. Rum. CHECK. Without Rum for the kiddos. CHECK. I could drink this every day. Did I mention I hate eggnog?
I made this for the first time over the holidays. I substituted Bacardi 151 for light run. My husband and friends loved it! I will definitely make this again.

Yes Indeed... This Conquito recipe is a hit! Along with this recipe, I followed Shannon's revise, one of the commentaries. Many of my guests from my 2016 New Year's party gravitated to this cocktail and finished it to the last drop.
Loved this recipe. I also added nutmeg, two cinnamon sticks to the bottle and coconut water instead of plain water. Will make it again!

Well I definitely put my spin on it. I use fat free evaporated milk and fat free condensed milk. You wouldn't know the difference. Then I add 1 cup of white Bacardi rum and 1/2 cup rum chata. No it's not too much alcohol. Truthfully it could've taken another 1/2 of Bacardi. And of course I added all the other stuff. I used all the alcohol and filled 16 of the 24oz jars in the picture. I gave them as gifts.
This was my first time making Coquito and it was a hit!! No more paying someone to make it. Now, thanks to the originator of this recipe, and this website, I can make it myself.

I followed this recipe almost exactly...I do not like cloves, so I used nutmeg. It was good, but too heavy for me. It also seemed to have too much spice for me. I added extra water and rum to my taste each time I had a glass, and it was good. I also made the other PR Coquito recipe on here that doesn't have eggs in it, and liked it so much more. Then I tried both with coconut rum and water, and they were delicious!
oh my goodness...so yuuuuuuuummy! ...used coconut milk instead of sweetened condensed milk, and coconut water instead of regular water ...used golden rum and 3/4 cup with a 1/2 teaspoon of cardamon.

I love it! I've been in charge of making the family coquito for years, unfortunately I didn't know how! I've used this recipe soooo many time and I didn't have to switch or swap anything! Except this year, that im leaving out the run because we have young kids that want to try it and older people on medications. Other than that 5 stars all around! Best tasting coquito I've ever tried! Buen provecho!

I did not add water. I added 2 cinnamon sticks to the evaporated milk and heated on low for 10 min. watching closely so not to scorch. Let cool down completely and use sieve while adding other ingredients. I also used Don Q Cristal Rum. Of course use as much rum to taste. Been Approvecho! For a bit more flavor you can also add Caption Morgans which kicks it up a notch. There are hundreds of variations to Coquito so don't be intimidated into thinking there is one right way to do it. My great-grandmother from Puerto Rico insisted that you never put egg yolks in. It is not intended to be Egg Nog. (And always use fresh coconut shredded add evaporated milk, use cheese cloth to squeeze 
out milk.)

This was my first time making this recipe it was AWESOME!!!!! I will never drink store brought eggnog again...I replaced the water with coconut milk and used 1 cup of rum. I also added a little more of the spices than directed and vanilla flavoring!!!! It was very simple this is going to be a tradition for here on out!!!!!

Definitely one of the better Coquito recipes out there. =] My family is from Puerto Rico and there is something about my abuela's that I couldn't quite get right. This recipe comes the closest to hers. Now, I did what ShannonS recommended **for the most part**, but I'm not sure how in the world, but mine ended up being about 2 gallons! (Probably used more alcohol xP Yum!) 

I used authentic Caribbean rum (thank you family!) and for the lighter weights of my friends who aren't too fond of "strong flavors", I used some Malibu in their portion with a shot of the good stuff. (Yay! More for me!)

I deviated and made my own leche condensada, but I didn't boil it down until it was completely thickened, which allowed me to remove the water from the recipe. I also only used about 3/4 of what the recipe called for and found it to be just right. I also boiled a cinnamon stick in with the leche evaporada.

Highly recommend this recipe. Also, play around with it. Tasting as you go is the best part! I'm not too fond of cloves, so them down a bit and upped the cinnamon.

The coquito doesn't need eggs and cloves just 2 cans of cream of coconut 1 can of evaporated milk 1 can of coconut milk vanilla cinnamon coconut rum and you can add a cinnamon stick to the recipient where you will store the coquito plus you need to let it rest in the fridge for at least 2 days so it can gain its consistency :-)

I really liked this! I used coconut milk because the store I went to didn't seem to have the cream of coconut and I used 6 oz of regular milk when heating the eggs because I forgot to get the evap milk so I just reduced the amount of milk for the recipe. In the end, I added a little more rum and a shot of buttershots! I will be keeping this recipe for sure!

I made this a 2nd time but for those who don't like alcohol, I omitted the Rum and substituted the amount with whole milk, then added alcohol per glass for those who wanted it.

I've had this drink before, but made by my latino friends. Searched for a recipe and came across this one. This was my first time making it and it came out grea! Sooo easy. I do not have a double broiler, so I just used a normal pot and carefully eyed it as not to let it stick to the pot while on low to medium heat stirring constantly. It was fine. I used Bacardi Coconut Rum. Deeelishh!
Delicious! I find the rum flavor lessens after its been refrigerated awhile so our family doubled the rum. will make again. Nice for gifts!
